Thus, from a geometric point of view, the number \sqrt{2} has a natural place in the number system. Yet, it is not the ratio of any two integers. One way to see this is by the following proof by contradiction:

The following argument will show that if there were integers a and b such that a/b = \sqrt{2}, with no common divisor in a,b, then a and b would have to be both even. But then a and b have the common divisor 2, a contradiction, and so the assumption that \sqrt{2} is a ratio of two integers must be false.

Thus b^2 and, hence, b are even. So we see that a and b have the common divisor 2, a contradiction to the assumption that a and b have no common divisor.
Thus we have evidence that there are points on the number line which do not correspond to any ratio of integers. We call such numbers ‘irrational’ for short.

Some reports about the discovery of irrational numbers paint quite a dramatic picture: among historians there is wide agreement that, within the school of Pythagorean philosophers, Hippasus of Metapontum discovered that \sqrt{2} was irrational. Up to that point, however, the Pythagoreans believed that every number was a ratio of integers. Hippasus' discovery contradicted this belief, and according to some reports he was punished by being drowned at sea.
